title: 藏語 Tibetan Studies
text:
今年2025四月開始學習藏語，這裏紀錄我所用到的學習資源和對我來説有用的學習方法。我并不是光靠自學，而是同時有去上課，聼老師的發音和得到糾正是非常重要的。在課下，我會每天發一到三個小時用以下的資源復習并且學習我在課上沒學到的。
每天學習前可以念文殊菩薩心咒求加持。
All the resources listed below can be used by English speakers to learn Tibetan. For some of them, the teachers teach in Chinese, while some teaches in Tibetan or English (marked with asterisk*). I see these resources as supplemental or for self-study in addition attending in-person classes because it is important to see and hear directly how the teachers pronounce each word and get feedback.
I usually start each learning session by chanting praise to Manjushri.


藏漢字典
藏英字典 Tibetan - English dictionary
Monlam app (iphone only) or website (select 3rd option from drop down menu above the search bar for Tibetan to English, 4th option for English to Tibetan
THL Tibetan to English Translation Tool





要多聼每個字母的發音，邊聽邊大聲跟讀（一定要大聲，這樣容易記住也可以聽聽自己的發音對不對）
剛開始會感覺很難，特別是ང的發音，對我最有幫助的這個字母的發音解釋是 “sing” 裏面的 “-ng” 音 + a (nga)，多練就可以發對音了！
一般外國人學藏語是直接學烏金字體，但是藏族小孩一開始是學烏梅字體。我的阿尼朋友們跟我說一般她們寫字都是用烏梅，寫筆記比烏金快。我一開始在寺裡學藏語，老師是教烏梅，然後同時另外自學烏金。我覺得一開始兩個一起學比較有效。
學烏梅可以參考這本書
烏梅字體筆畫練習
我每天一般一半時間練習烏梅，一半練習烏金。學藏語的頭兩個星期我會默寫這兩個字體的30字母，把它們都背下來，然後陸續開始學上加字，後加字等等。對我來說烏梅的上加字和下加字比烏金複雜，我容易搞混（比如說不知道是yata還是rata)，學的時候跟烏金對比會比較好認。
第一個星期我學習用的資源：

丹增南卓仁波切教的第 1 堂｜基礎藏語班

Unit 1: The alphabet | Tibetan Language School



繼續多多練習輔音字母，這個星期也開始學習四個元音符號

藏語四元音*
數字1-10 丹達讀逗 4分鐘藏語教室 數字篇-1 Number 1-10

數字兒歌



如果過去兩個星期堅持每天都堅持背誦和默寫30字母的話，這個星期應該所有字母都記的差不多了，這個星期可以繼續複習四元音的發音，和開始學上加字和下加字
讀藏語有點像在做數學的加減乘除，所以基礎要打好，記住30個字母以及它們的正確發音是繼續學以下部分的前提，慢慢的我們就可以讀所有看到的藏語字
1）四元音複習*

上加字* 上加字是先讀上加字再讀輔音字母，最後讀整個字的音：ང ra + ཀ ga + ད tha = རྐ ga
下加字* 下加字是先讀輔音字母的音，再讀下加字，最後讀整個字：ཀ ga + ང ra + ད tha = ཀྲ dra

title: 社會心理學 social psychology and how I graduated with a PhD in 4 years
text:
我從高中就開始對心理學感興趣，修心理學課的時候我頭一次開始向内看，我學到的知識然我更加瞭解自己和理解她人與人類所共享的許多相似的心理需求。
年少時沒預想到我會一直讀完博士，拿到學位后終於可以稱自己為社會心理學家，所以算完成了我的一大夢想。大二的時候我接觸到了正念冥想，這變成了我的主要研究，同時，我最想要研究的是人們如何能夠無分別心的對外人有同理心并且願幫助TA人。



就像一個系裏有很多學科，心理學也分幾個不同的方面。大部人想到心理學一般是臨床心理學方面或者心理咨詢。社會心理學 是研究人們的思想，感情，和行爲是怎麽被TA人所影響的。當人們聽到我是學心理學的，很多人會問 “那你知道我現在在想什麽嗎？” 答案是不能。
我覺得大衆很容易忽視心理學的科學部分。心理學是社會科學，它的基礎是科學的思想和研究。這特別是社會心理學最吸引我的一部分，我的教授們常說任何人們感興趣的東西，社會科學家應該都有研究過（或可以去研究）。
什麽是科學的思想?
對我來説，好的科學家應該以開放的心態去學習，探索未知，和質疑已知。科學是不停更新的，主流理論 （theory) 也有可能被新的研究成果推翻，我們需要靈活的去持續更新自己的認知。所以學心理學并不能一勞永逸。

text: how to grad school

title: 社會心理學 social psychology and how I graduated with a PhD in 4 years
text:
resources I found useful
During the first two years of grad school, I spent some time diving into research such as “how to work efficiently” as productivity was valued highly in grad school. I found one key to “efficiency,” and by that I meant working on what I need to get done for the degree while still preserving enough time for doing things that sustain me. In grad school, one can easily revolve one’s life to center around research. Therefore, it is important to set a boundary on work time. I find time blocking especially useful to structure my work schedule for the weekdays. At the beginning of each semester, I will go over the syllabus for each class, and put in the deadlines for exams and assignments into the calendar. Additionally, I will also block out time slots preceding those deadlines of what I think approximately will take me to complete to assignment or studies. I will also put into calendar major research phases such as study design and data analysis. Once a week (I did Friday afternoon), I will take about 10-15 minutes to plan out what I will work on for the following week. I will literally “block” out different time slots on Google Calendar and color code them based on the type of work they are (e.g., dark blue for meditation sessions, yellow for classes, gray for meetings, dark green for paid work, red for deadlines). This way, I have a clear idea of what I need to do for that day. This planning also ensures that I finished all the work on time and usually a bit earlier than the deadline. Of course, the schedule can be modified through out the day as I went about it but outlining it ahead of time eliminates some of the time of feeling lost and wondering what I need to do.
The first two years of grad school, I was working almost everyday, which felt like I was always working. This did not work since I felt burnt out every summer break. Then, I decided to keep the weekend free for only doing things with friends and other activities I found relaxing.
Meditation was a crucial part of how I was able to remain calm through the ups and downs of PhD. I learned how to practice mindfulness mediation when I was sophomore in college. When grad school started, I realized it was important for me to keep a consistent practice because I felt a heightened level of stress that I never felt before. So I usually meditate each day for around 20 to 40 minutes. I also goes to a in person group meditation once a week as I find I can meditation deeper sometimes in a group setting and it is nice to connect with other people who is also into meditation and Buddhism.

title: 社會心理學 social psychology and how I graduated with a PhD in 4 years
section: what to do with a PhD and different ways of life
text:
what to do with a PhD and different ways of life
For me, I never intended to stay in academia and become a professor so I go on a quite nontraditional path during and post-grad school. One of the main reasons why I chose to specialize in social psychology is because I see that it is relevant for everyone and for our daily lives. I want to be able to apply what I learned to have the most impact I could. It makes more sense for me to consider options that is more in the applied field where my work can possibly have influence on education and policy. One event that changed how I proceed with grad school is when I met with two professors at VCU to discuss my interests and they commented that if you want to take the nontraditional route then you cannot follow what everyone else is doing (to become a professor). Thus, I started exploring groups that share my values and vision. Given my research expertise in intergroup relations and my own experience as a Chinese American, I started working with a non-profit org that focuses on promoting the education of Asian American history and constructive US-China relations. I have continued this work along with my wish to alleviate suffering that farmed animals experience, which I worked with another non-profit to promote the education of compassionate and sustainable behavior toward other living beings and the environment.

title: 藏語基础入门 intro to Tibetan: for beginners
text:
今年2025四月開始學習藏語，這裏紀錄我所用到的學習資源和對我來説有用的學習方法。我并不是光靠自學，而是同時有去上課，聼老師的發音和得到糾正是非常重要的。在課下，我會每天發一到三個小時用以下的資源復習并且學習我在課上沒學到的。
All the resources listed below can be used by English speakers to learn Tibetan. For some of them, the teachers teach in Chinese, while some teaches in Tibetan or English (marked with asterisk*). I see these resources as supplemental or for self-study in addition attending in-person classes because it is important to see and hear directly how the teachers pronounce each word and get feedback.
Please see the other blog post called “Tibetan studying resources” for additional materials such as dictionaries to use.




要多聼每個字母的發音，邊聽邊大聲跟讀（一定要大聲，這樣容易記住也可以聽聽自己的發音對不對）
剛開始會感覺很難，特別是ང的發音，對我最有幫助的這個字母的發音解釋是 “sing” 裏面的 “-ng” 音 + a (nga)，多練就可以發對音了！
一般外國人學藏語是直接學烏金字體，但是藏族小孩一開始是學烏梅字體。我的阿尼朋友們跟我說一般她們寫字都是用烏梅，寫筆記比烏金快。我一開始在寺裡學藏語，老師是教烏梅，然後同時另外自學烏金。我覺得一開始兩個一起學比較有效。
學烏梅可以參考這本書
烏梅字體筆畫練習
我每天一般一半時間練習烏梅，一半練習烏金。學藏語的頭兩個星期我會默寫這兩個字體的30字母，把它們都背下來，然後陸續開始學上加字，後加字等等。對我來說烏梅的上加字和下加字比烏金複雜，我容易搞混（比如說不知道是yata還是rata)，學的時候跟烏金對比會比較好認。
第一個星期我學習用的資源：

丹增南卓仁波切教的第 1 堂｜基礎藏語班

網站*

讀藏語有點像在做數學的加減乘除，所以基礎要打好，記住30個字母以及它們的正確發音是繼續學以下部分的前提，慢慢的我們就可以讀所有看到的藏語字
1）四元音複習*

上加字* 上加字是先讀上加字再讀輔音字母，最後讀整個字的音：ང ra + ཀ ga + ད tha = རྐ ga
下加字* 下加字是先讀輔音字母的音，再讀下加字，最後讀整個字：ཀ ga + ང ra + ད tha = ཀྲ dra

Sambhota Schools*: ཀ字母單詞 #1 ཅ字母單詞 #2 ཏ字母單詞 #3 པ字母單詞 #4 ཙ字母單詞 #5 ཞ字母單詞 #6

ར字母單詞 #7
ཧ字母單詞 #8

下加字復習 Subscript*

ཡ་བཏགས་yatag
ར་བཏགས་ratag
ལ་བཏགས་latag
ཝ་ཟུར་wasur

རྗེས་འཇུག་བཅུ།怎麼讀有後加字的詞 | how to pronounce words with suffix*




After one month, it is possible to pronouce almost all the words in Tibetan if we study and practice the alphabet and adjacent letters thoroughly. Therefore, it is very important to build this foundation in the first month.
Here is another review of the stacked letters to practice pronounciation.
Some pronounciation notes to keep in mind from Tibetan Language School: - If you have a single consonant letter with a vowel letter on top (e.g. ལོ་), then the consonant letter is the main letter. - Prefix letters and superscript letters cause some main letters to become voiced (e.g. th turns into “d”, and kh into “g”): འདེབས་ dep སྒོ་ go - prefix letters, ག་ད་བ་མ་འ་, are silent letters with no pronunciation in and of themselves. However, depending on the following main letter, the prefix letter may change the pronunciation of a syllable. - The syllables བ་ and བོ་ are pronounced as “wa” and “wo” respectively when they’re not the first syllable of a word: ཇོ་བོ་ chhowo བྱ་བྲལ་བ་ chha trhälwa

when the main letter བ་ is preceded by the suffix letter ད་, the two letters together are pronounced as a high-tone w, and this w may also become silent before the vowel u
Most of the time, the suffix letter ད་ is completely silent, the suffix letters ས་ and འ་ are generally silent

when preceding a nasal consonant (i.e. when the following syllable has ང་, ཉ་, ན་ or མ་ as its main letter), the suffix letter ག་ tends to be pronounced like ང་: བདག་མེད་ dangme
The suffix letter འ་ must be added to any syllable that has only a prefix letter and a main letter, with no vowel letter
the post-suffix letter ས་ cannot occur after the suffix letters ན་, ར་, or ལ་
In most two-syllable words the second syllable is pronounced high-tone, even if it would naturally be low-tone. The exception is that in two-syllable verbs, the second syllable is typically pronounced low-tone, even if would naturally be high-tone.
Often in three syllable words, the first syllable is treated as one chunk, and the second and third syllables are treated as another chunk.
Consonant restoration typically happens when the first syllable of the word is an open syllable, meaning that it ends in a vowel sound. After an open syllable, a silent letter at the beginning of the second syllable has the space to reappear (or be “restored”) in the pronunciation. The restored consonant is generally pronounced as if it were the suffix letter of the first syllable, even though it’s not.

Here are the usual restorations of the five prefix letters: བཅུ་གཅིག་ chukchik (restored “k” from the prefix letter ག་) ཉི་ཤུ་རྩ་དགུ་ nyishu tsargu (restored “r” from the prefix letter ད་) ས་བཀྲ་ saptra (restored “p” from the prefix letter བ་) ཨ་མདོ་ amdo (restored “m” from the prefix letter མ་) དེ་འདྲ་ thendra (restored “n” from the prefix letter འ་)
The restored prefix letter མ་ causes the same kinds of changes as འ་ after both open and closed syllables: གཟའ་མཇུག་ sanjuk ས་མགོ་ sang-go ཡིག་མགོ་ ying-go
數字 1-100 numbers*
數字 1-10
數字11-30
數字31-60
數字61-100
數字規則 number rules
Now, we can start learning grammar and reading text. I will create another post for intermediate Tibetan.

title:
依然 Yiran
Denise Zheng, PhD
text:
我是依然。1998出生於紐約，小時候在福建長大，然後中學開始在美國讀書一直到快博士畢業。讀博最後一個學期的時候我決定開始旅居，2023年12月我先去了南美洲，然後4月到台灣并在臺南遠程完成社會心理學博士學位論文答辯。在台灣生活的日子讓我意識到我最喜歡在亞洲生活。因爲我的研究跟冥想和慈悲心相關，我開始想深入學習佛學，同時也在印度學藏語和辯經。我會在這個部落格記錄旅途中的聞思修，寫作和攝影。
Hello world. My name is Yiran. I’m a social psychologist and contemplative scientist (research meditation and compassion). I’m Chinese American, lived in China for 9 years and the US for more than 15 years. When I was finishing my PhD in 2024, I decided to live internationally, mostly in Asia. I like to take photographs of the moments that touched me and reflect on things I’m learning so I’m sharing them here.
